In a separate action against the Monitor, security officials went to its editorial offices on Thursday night and told the management that it was being closed until it paid a fine of 15 million Sudanese pounds (about US$6,000) that was outstanding from a court conviction last year
Sudan has an Islamic-orientated government and a substantial Christian minority
A state security court suspended a newspaper critical of the government Saturday after convicting it of publishing religiously inflammatory material

ldc_scope.charseq: A state security court suspended a newspaper critical of the government Saturday after convicting it of publishing religiously inflammatory material, the newspaper's lawyer said

extent.charseq: The court convicted the paper of violating article 25 of the Press Law

ldc_scope.charseq: The court convicted the paper of violating article 25 of the Press Law, which prohibits the publication of material that defames religion or incites religiously unacceptable activity

extent.charseq: violating article 25 of the Press Law
The Khartoum Monitor may not appear for two months and must pay a fine of 1 million Sudanese pounds

ldc_scope.charseq: The Khartoum Monitor may not appear for two months and must pay a fine of 1 million Sudanese pounds (about US$400), lawyer Ngor Olang Ngor told The Associated Press

extent.charseq: the paper would pay the fine

ldc_scope.charseq: Ngor said the paper would pay the fine but it would also appeal the verdict
Failure to pay the fine would result in a two-month extension of the suspension

extent.charseq: the south of the country, where a civil war has been waged for 20 years

ldc_scope.charseq: The sentence was the latest in a series of state actions against the Monitor, the only English language daily in Sudan and a leading critic of conditions in the south of the country, where a civil war has been waged for 20 years

ldc_scope.charseq: The court ruling stated that the verdict and sentence would be submitted to the National Press Council, a government-appointed body, for approval, Ngor said
The charges arose from letters-to-the-editor published last month that dealt with religion

extent.charseq: Earlier this week, security police detained the Monitor's managing editor, Nhial Bol, for 24 hours
